The transition into these materials occurs when the density of electrons to the one-third power times the Bohr radius is greater than a critical value. They can be identified by the presence of a (*) second change in the Hall coefficient’s sign during doping, which is part of a general property that is found alongside antiferromagnetic order. tossups.text: The general form for a wavefunction with this property is a displacement operator acting on a “squeeze” operator acting on the vacuum state, in quantum optics. At finite temperature, the density matrix of systems described by this term has a Bose–Einstein distribution of photon number. Wavefunctions with this property are indexed by a single complex number. Matrix elements for any observable of the basis of wavefunctions with this property are computed by first writing the observable in normal-ordered form. Since the basis of these wavefunctions is (*) overcomplete, just the diagonal elements of that matrix are sufficient to determine all elements. Wavefunctions with this property are eigenfunctions of the lowering operator and display behavior that is clearly limiting towards the classical harmonic oscillator’s motion. For 10 points, name this term also used to describe laser light, which is spatially and temporally in-phase.

In thin-film and nanoparticle form, the anatase mineral form of (*) titanium dioxide has been shown to catalyze this process in an effect discovered by Honda and Fujishima. A biomimetic calcium-manganese complex has been developed to drive this process. Exchange current densities of 10-to-the-minus-9 can be achieved by using platinum electrodes for this process, which requires 1.229 volts plus an overpotential calculable using the Tafel equation. Absorption of a photon by P680 performs—for 10 points—what process that produces oxygen and hydrogen gas by passing current through a common liquid?
tossups.formatted_answer: electrolysis of water [or oxygen evolution or water splitting or photo-oxidation of water or hydrogen production; prompt on partial answer] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: Despite being larger than this compound, carborane ligands called nido-dicarbollides have similar reactivity to it. A group of catalysts containing this ligand are made more efficient after reaction with methyl·alumin·oxane, forming a catalytic system named for Walter Kaminsky. Those catalysts, where two of this ligand are bound to titanium-group elements, are the second generation of homogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts. Two equivalents of this compound are joined by a linker group in compounds described by the prefix ansa. A manganese atom bonds to three carbonyl groups and a methylated form of compound to make an anti-knock agent. Titanium bonds to two equivalents of this compound and two bridging methyl groups in a carbonyl methylation reagent developed by (*) Fred Tebbe. Two equivalents of this compound have a hapticity of 5 when they bond to iron to form the sandwich compound ferrocene. For 10 points, name this cyclic hydrocarbon with formula C5H6.
tossups.answer: cyclopentadiene [accept cyclopentadienyl] <Science - Chemistry>

The Drosophila HP1a protein has been shown to undergo this process leading to hetero·chromatin formation; those domains formed during this process are sensitive to the disruption of weak hydrophobic interactions and restrict diffusion of small molecules. Silver staining of many cell types shows nuclear aggregates called (*) Cajal bodies which are formed by this phenomenon, which are rich in RNAs and ribo·nucleo·proteins. Proteins or RNAs that undergo this process often have large repeat regions. Ostwald ripening is a version of this phenomenon that occurs in solid sols or liquid sols. For 10 points, name this phenomenon that occurs when a liquid-liquid colloid, like oil suspended in water, is allowed to sit.
tossups.answer: liquid-liquid phase separation [or liquid-liquid demixing, or liquid droplet formation, or biomolecular condensation, or spinodal decomposition, also accept any reference to formation of “membrane-less organelles”; prompt on condensation or phase change; do not accept “precipitation”, “amyloid formation”, or “deposition”] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: The bacterial enzyme SpnF in Saccharo·polyspora spinosa catalyzes a reaction of this general class. In the bacterial biosynthesis of the pyrrole ring of cobalamin, the conversion of precorrin-8x to hydrogeno·byrinate is a reaction of this general type. An example of one of these reactions occurs in the shikimic acid pathway in the production of prephenic acid, catalyzed by chorismate mutase. (*) Selenium dioxide is used in a reaction of this general type to form allylic alcohols. It’s not hydroxylation, but two separate examples of this class of reactions occur in the conversion of 7-de·hydro·cholesterol to vitamin D3 in the skin, both allowed under UV catalysis. Thermally allowed 4-electron examples of this class of reactions must either have a con·rotatory mechanism or involve an antara·facial migration. For 10 points, name this class of reactions governed by the Woodward–Hoffman rules.
tossups.answer: pericyclic reactions [anti-prompt on Diels–Alder, cycloaddition, sigmatropic rearrangement, Claisen rearrangement, or electrocyclization] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: The Weitzenbock identity states that two different definitions of this form in differential geometry differ only by a zero-order linear operator. If the vorticity is everywhere zero, the Navier–Stokes equation can be reformulated into a much simpler equation involving this operator. This operator admits a generalization on Riemannian manifolds computed by taking the trace of the Hessian. The proof of Earnshaw’s theorem begins by applying this operator to the (*) energy of a magnetic dipole, which returns zero. This operator acting on “one over the polar coordinate r” is equal to “4 pi times the 3D delta function.” If this operator applied to a function is zero, the function’s value at a point equals the average of values on a sphere surrounding the point. The kinetic energy term of the 3D quantum Hamiltonian is equal to “negative h-bar-squared over 2m times this operator.” For 10 points, name this quantity equal to del-squared, the sum of the second-derivatives of a function in all of its coordinates.
tossups.answer: Laplacian [accept del-squared before mentioned] <Science - Physics>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by the Editors (4)  Bonuses

tossups.text: The cephalic vein is a superficial vein overlaying this bone, and Smith’s and Colles’ fractures occur in its distal aspect. De Quervain teno·synovitis involves a non-inflammatory thickening of the first extensor compartment’s sheath, which overlays this bone. An associated nerve that shares this bone’s name arises from the posterior cord and can be compressed in the supinator canal, leading to its namesake “tunnel syndrome.” Preschool-age children often experience subluxation of this bone’s head due to slight overgrowth of the (*) annular ligament, which is often attributed to “nursemaids” pulling on the child’s arm. The antero·lateral branch of the deep brachial artery becomes this bone’s deep artery once it crosses the elbow. This bone abuts the scaphoid and lunate carpal bones and articulates with the capitulum of the humerus. For 10 points, name this bone that’s bound to the ulna by an inter·osseus membrane.
tossups.answer: radius [accept radial tunnel syndrome] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: These sets can be represented by using a Markov partition to generate a finite set of symbols. Under Stephen Smale’s horseshoe map, the points in these sets that fall within the original square form a set whose horizontal and vertical components are homeomorphic to the Cantor Set. In the two-dimensional case, if these sets do not contain a fixed point, they must be periodic according to the Poincaré–Bendixson theorem. These sets are (*) “homoclinic” if they approach an equilibrium point going either forward or backward in time. A periodic solution to a differential equation forms a “closed” example of these sets. These sets can spiral into a limit cycle or other kinds of attractors. Periodic examples of these sets are dense in chaotic systems. For 10 points, name these sets traced out by a dynamical system’s evolution function given a set of initial conditions.
tossups.answer: orbits [accept trajectory or connections; prompt on flow] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: Two of this non-water ligand are found at the active site in the ribonucleotide reductase enzyme. Each perovskite unit cell contains three of this anionic ligand. No transition metal complexes with octahedral symmetry and d-electron counts beyond five that contain this terminal ligand have been prepared. The active site of the (*) manganese-calcium complex at the core of photosystem II contains five of this ligand’s bridging type. Cytochrome P450 enzymes form a reactive intermediate in which iron is in a +4 oxidation state and bound to this ligand. That aforementioned “wall” of this anionic ligand is due to the nature of the double bond that it forms to its metal. tossups.text: This phenomenon is present in the racemization of biphenyls with a “steric,” rather than “electronic,” explanation. Its “reverse form” is observed in alkyl metal hydrides undergoing reductive or beta-elimination, as the forming bond in the transition state has an agostic interaction with the metal center. This effect’s value can be much larger than its classical theoretical maximum value when the reaction (*) proceeds by quantum tunneling. Its strength is proportional to the product of a first term encoding the ratio of symmetry numbers for chemical species, a second term capturing the fraction of molecules in a vibrationally-excited state, and a third term equal to a ratio of vibrational zero-point energies. E2 reactions have a much larger value for this effect than E1 reactions because, in E2, the carbon-hydrogen bond is broken in the rate-determining step. For 10 points, name this effect defined as the ratio of reaction rates when different isotopes of the same element are present in the starting materials.
tossups.answer: kinetic isotope effect [or KIE; prompt on isotope effect] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: Description acceptable. In one portion of this process, the FHY3 gene was found to control the expression of stem cell regulator CLV3. Four hetero·tetrameric complexes bind to four regulatory CArG complexes in this process. A C2H2-type zinc finger protein called KNUCKLES represses the expression of WUS in this process. AGAMOUS and DEFICIENS are genes regulating this process; those genes contain a domain derived from a sequence stretch of a type II topo·isomerase. A defect in this pathway can create (*) reproductive verticils. Except for AP1, most genes in this process are MADS-box genes. The ABC model describes—for 10 points—what process of organogenesis in plants that produces sepals and petals?
tossups.answer: flower development [accept any answer indicating the growth of flowers] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: Donald Matteson’s group homologated compounds containing this hetero·atom using alpha-halogenated organo·lithium reagents like di·chloro·methyl·lithium. This heteroatom forms a high-temperature ferromagnet with calcium, and a similar compound it forms with lanthanum has a very low work function; in both of those compounds, this atom is found in an octahedral polyatomic ion with minus-2 charge. It can form organic derivatives for chemical synthesis by reaction with alpha-pinene or (*) pinacol. A magnesium compound with two of this atom in its formula unit is a type I superconductor at 30 Kelvin. A D2h compound containing this heteroatom can be described by a combination of two separate M·O diagrams, one of which has contributions of a B3u and an A·g set from its two central hydrogen atoms. Eleven of this atom bond to a carbon atom and eleven halogen atoms to form a superacid. For 10 points, name this element that forms three-center two-electron bonds in its compounds with hydrogen.
tossups.answer: boron [or B] <Science - Chemistry>

It’s not heat capacity, but, in a Debye gas of phonons at a low temperature, this quantity scales as the cube of the temperature. The amount of this quantity per particle in a system equals “the negative derivative of chemical potential with respect to temperature, at constant pressure.” This quantity’s rate of (*) production by an engine is equal to the heat flow times the difference between the reciprocals of the cold and hot operating temperatures. In adiabatic steps, this quantity for a system is conserved. In the classical limit, the Sackur–Tetrode equation can compute this quantity. For 10 points, give this quantity equal to “k log W.”
tossups.answer: entropy <Science - Physics>

tossups.text: Description acceptable. The ability of C·U·X·1 to upregulate cilia-related genes has been shown to play a role in the evolution of this phenomenon. The Weis–Fogh mechanism is a version of this phenomenon, and frenulo-retinacular coupling is an adaptation to increase the efficiency of this phenomenon. William Beebe [bee-bee] proposed an intermediate stage in the development of this phenomenon. Asynchronous muscle, which contracts multiple times per nerve impulse, is used in this (*) behavior in insects, in which it has direct and indirect forms. Microraptor is thought to an intermediate in the evolution of this behavior, which may have been preceded by incline running. For 10 points, name this behavior found only in insects, pterosaurs, bats, and birds.
tossups.answer: powered flight [or word equivalents] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: The most direct treatment of this condition can lead to a non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that presents similarly to ARDS and is called TRALI [“trolley”]. In susceptible individuals, this symptom can be caused by a virus with a single-stranded DNA genome that also causes a childhood exanthem in a “slapped-cheek” distribution. Its opposite can be caused by a para·neoplastic syndrome of renal cell carcinoma. Autoimmune diseases cause this general symptom because (*) hepcidin is an acute phase reactant and thus elevated in chronic immune stimulation, which is called “[this symptom] of chronic disease.” Mutations in spectrin can lead to a hereditary form of this condition called spherocytosis. High MCV and hypersegmented neutrophils are present in a form of it usually due to B12 or folate deficiency, and B12 deficiency is the culprit of its “pernicious” form. For 10 points, name this general condition most commonly caused by a lack of iron.
tossups.answer: anemia [accept more specific answers like sickle cell anemia, pernicious anemia, etc.] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: Either HPLC or a form of this technique using fiber optics is used to monitor the dissolution profile of pharmaceuticals. In this technique, the octant rule can be used to predict the sign of the Cotton effect, which is used to distinguish between enantiomers. This technique is used to determine association constants between host and guest molecules via the Benesi–Hildebrand method. The ratio of two measurements obtained via this technique is between (*) 1.7 and 2 for pure samples of DNA. Depending on whether the compound being imaged is homo- or hetero-annular, a base value of 214 or 253 is used to predict the wavelength maximum in this technique, which typically occurs due to a HOMO–LUMO transition. The Woodward–Fieser rules are used to predict the results of this technique, which is particularly useful for systems with extended conjugation. For 10 points, name this form of spectroscopy that uses wavelengths slightly shorter than infrared spectroscopy.
tossups.answer: UV/Vis spec [or ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: Examples of these substances associated with Cibicides and Cibicidoides have C13/C12 [C-13 to C-12] ratios that lag behind atmospheric levels and are used to track fluid parcels’ circulation. Transfer functions for comparing these substances use the prevalence of Emiliania huxleyi as a physical paleoproxy. The distribution of component size in these substances is bimodal and decreases over time as its larger component dissolves, resulting in a remainder of red clay. One type of them dominates the other in the Arctic, Antarctic, and the Equator due to the influx of nutrients from upwelling. Their diagenesis can result in the formation of (*) chert from discarded tests and, in other cases, begins with the needle-like isoform aragonite. These substances’ carbonaceous variety cannot form below the compensation depth and is primarily derived from coccolithophores, while their siliceous type is formed from diatoms. For 10 points, name these biogenous benthic sediments formed from 30% or more planktonic skeletons.
tossups.answer: oozes [accept siliceous ooze, diatomaceous ooze, carbonaceous ooze, coccolithophore ooze, or foraminiferal ooze; prompt on oceanic sediment or pelagic sediment; prompt on calcium carbonate, aragonite, or calcite; prompt on silica, or silicon dioxide] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: It’s not metformin, but an analog of this protein has been approved to treat a condition caused by mutations in A·G·P·A·T·2, called Berardinelli–Seip syndrome. A G2548A polymorphism in this protein, and a Q223R polymorphism in its receptor are the subject of several meta-analyses. By indirectly stimulating the release of kiss·peptin, this protein has a permissive effect on the induction of puberty. This hormone increases the secretion of CART and alpha-MSH, and downregulates the secretion of agouti-related peptide and neuropeptide Y, when it binds to its receptors in the arcuate nucleus. This hormone has a similar effect to (*) peptide YY. Coleman et. al. discovered this hormone by parabiosing, or literally sewing together, mice with the db mutation to either normal or ob mice, the latter of whom experienced significant weight loss due to this hormone, which has the opposite effect from ghrelin. For 10 points, name this hormone secreted by adipose tissue that signals satiety.
tossups.answer: leptin <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: This substance is commonly used in tandem one-pot oxidation coupling reactions, such as in the direct coupling of an alcohol to a Wittig reagent to generate an alkene. The Scheidt group used N-heterocyclic carbenes as catalysts in a cyanide-free modification of a reaction in which this molecule oxidizes benzylic aldehydes to esters; that reaction being modified is the Corey–Gilman–Ganem reaction. This substance can selective oxidize “activated” alcohols like allylic or benzylic alcohols to aldehydes or ketones; this is because a resonance-stabilized radical intermediate is formed when this molecule adds to an alcohol and its central atom is reduced to a (*) +3 oxidation state. The positive electrode in alkaline batteries is formed from this substance. This compound’s natural ore is pyrolusite. For 10 points, name this mild oxidizing agent whose central atom has a +4 oxidation state, formed as a byproduct of reactions involving permanganate in neutral solution.
tossups.answer: manganese dioxide or manganese(IV) oxide [or MnO2; prompt on manganese oxide] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: Except for mirror supports, all of the parts of this currently-active telescope are made of beryllium. This telescope is separated into “cold” and “warm” portions due to its cryogenic assembly, while its primary mirror is cooled to 5.5 Kelvin by that assembly. MIPS and IRAC [“eye-rack”] are two instruments used on this telescope, which found the Double Helix Nebula near the center of the Milky Way inside a “zone of avoidance.” Operating in the same radiation range as (*) SOFIA, this telescope discovered the largest batch of exoplanets in the TRAPPIST-1 system. In 2005, this telescope became the first to gather light from hot Jupiters. Its namesake pioneered the study of the interstellar medium and was one of the first to suggest launching a telescope out of the atmosphere for clearer resolution. The James Webb Telescope will combine the utility of this telescope with Hubble. For 10 points, name this 2003-launched NASA telescope that is set to retire on January 30th, 2020, which captures infrared light.
tossups.answer: Spitzer Space Telescope <Science - Other>

tossups.text: Heterogeneous tumors formed by these cells contain patches of sparse myxoid tissue and spindle cells, interspersed with dense eosinophilic patches containing palisading cells. Those regions are named for Antoni and may contain Verocay bodies. These cells are formed from the same progenitors as melanocytes and the adrenal medulla’s entero·chromaffin cells. Mycobacterium leprae disseminates in the body by binding ti a receptor on their surface. A tumor predisposition syndrome caused by mutations in the (*) merlin gene sees the formation of bilateral benign tumors of these cells on cranial nerve VIII [eight] in neuro·fibro·matosis type II. They may have an “onion-bulb” appearance on silver stain, and Charcot–Marie–Tooth’s disease causes their compensatory hyperplasia. A substance in these cells includes protein zero and galacto·cerebroside and enables saltatory conduction, which is also performed by oligodendrocytes. For 10 points, name these glial cells that form the myelin sheath in the PNS.
tossups.answer: Schwann cells <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: Baz’ and Rybachenko proposed a form of this phenomenon that can determine traversal time for particles tunneling across a barrier. Pugh and Schiff name a form of this phenomenon caused due to changes in the metric near the Earth’s poles, which is a special case of a form named for two Austrian scientists that’s been measured by the LAGEOS satellites. This phenomenon accounts for a relativistic correction factor of (*) one-half in the largest term in the fine structure correction to the hydrogen atom. Gravity Probe B measured frame dragging, which causes its Lense–Thirring form. One form of this kind of motion is a Wigner rotation caused by successive boosts and is named for Llewllyn Thomas. tossups.text: Ethylene induces fruit ripening by binding to its receptor via a direct pi-orbital-to-d-orbital bond to this element. The MiniGrail sphere at Leiden University, made of an alloy of this element and 6% aluminum, is a resonant mass antenna cooled to 20 milliKelvin that is used to search for gravitational waves. This element is required by the enzyme that converts dopamine into norepinephrine, which is thought to explain why Menkes’ disease patients have CNS symptoms; those patients also have impaired lysyl oxidase action due to deficiency of this element. Carolyn (*) Bertozzi developed a strain-promoted reaction using difluorinated cyclo·octynes to avoid using this element in a reaction due to its cytotoxicity. Perhaps the best-known example of a Jahn–Teller distortion occurs in this element’s hexa-aquo complex with a d9 configuration. It’s not lithium, but this element is found in Gilman reagents. For 10 points, name this metallic element whose deficiency causes a syndrome of cirrhosis and CNS symptoms, named for British doctor Samuel Wilson.
tossups.answer: copper [or Cu] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: Four evolutionary stages in this field were laid out in a 2006 article by Mihail Roco. Tom Newman solved an early conjecture in this field in a method that involved Charles Dickens’ A Tale of Two Cities. The name of this field was coined in the book (*) Engines of Creation by K. Eric Drexler, who engaged in a multi-year debate with Richard Smalley on the feasibility of certain goals in this field. The concept of “swallowing the surgeon” was introduced in an early inspiration for this field, Richard Feynman’s talk “There’s Plenty of Room at the Bottom.” Much speculative work in this field is based on the creation of artificial molecular assemblers. tossups.text: A model of particle diffusion between two containers that obeys the H-theorem is named for this man. tossups.text: Warning: specific term required. HITS is an algorithm developed by Jon Kleinberg that computes two measures of this quantity. To solve the problem of spider traps and dangling nodes, an algorithm that calculates one type of this measure introduces a damping factor; that algorithm simulates the actions of a random walker with added teleportation to traverse links between nodes, and has its convergence guaranteed by the Perron–Frobenius theorem. One measure of this concept is named for Leo (*) Katz, and takes into account the total number of walks, not just the shortest one. One form of this measure is calculated by following the “links” between sites in the PageRank algorithm, and it has types like “betweenness” and “closeness.” The simplest way to quantify this concept is by looking at the degree of a node. For 10 points, name this measure that quantifies a node’s importance or how close it is to the “middle” of a graph.
tossups.answer: centrality [anti-prompt on betweenness or closeness; accept specific types of centrality, as long as centrality is mentioned; accept eigencentrality; prompt on “PageRank” after “links” is read] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: Up to 70% of T-cell ALLs have a gain of function mutation in a gene in this pathway essential for T-cell development. The neuronal migration glycoprotein reelin [reel-in] signals via this pathway. An arteri·opathy of the brain causing mini-strokes and damage to the white matter is due to germline mutations in a protein in this pathway; that disease is CADASIL. GLP-1, a homolog to the central protein in this pathway, acts as a membrane receptor for the distal tip signal. Fringe glycosyl·transferases act on the E·G·F repeats of the protein central to this pathway, which is cleaved by ADAM10 and gamma-secretase after ligands bind to it. In humans, (*) delta-like-ligand 4 inhibitors target a component of this pathway to prevent angiogenesis in tumors. Poulson showed that dysfunction of this pathway led to an embryonic lethal phenotype in Drosophila. For 10 points, partial loss of function in what pathway leads to the formation of dents on the wings of flies?
tossups.answer: Notch signaling pathway <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: Any real Banach space with this property embeds isometrically in the space of continuous real-valued functions on the unit interval, by the Banach–Mazur theorem. Considering the anti-diagonal of the Sorgenfrey plane shows that subsets of spaces with this property need not themselves have it. On Banach spaces with this property, one does not need the axiom of choice to prove the Hahn–Banach theorem. Any Hilbert space with this property is isomorphic to the sequence space “little-L 2.” By considering the set of polynomials with rational coefficients and applying the (*) Stone–Weierstrass theorem, one can show that the space of continuous functions on a compact interval has this property. Since the rational numbers have cardinality aleph-naught and their closure is the real line, the real line has this property. For 10 points, name this property of spaces that possess a countable dense subset, which also denotes differential equations in which the two variables can be put on different sides of the equals sign.
tossups.answer: separable [or word forms like separability; accept answers indicating the existence of a countable dense subset until “countable”] <Science - Other>

For 10 points, name this property of spaces that possess a countable dense subset, which also denotes differential equations in which the two variables can be put on different sides of the equals sign.
tossups.formatted_answer: separable [or word forms like separability; accept answers indicating the existence of a countable dense subset until “countable”] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: A formula to compute this concept’s “breath” calculates the Bhattacharya distance between the distribution of resources and the population distribution. Its “breath” can also be calculated by summing one over the sum of squares of proportions of individuals in each “resource state” in a uniformity measure developed by Richard Levins. When this concept is repeatedly (*) “pre-empted,” the relative abundance distribution takes the form of a geometric series. Robert MacArthur analogized its apportionment to randomly breaking a stick into pieces. George Hutchinson defined these concepts as n-dimensional hypervolumes in a space whose dimensions are environmental factors. Because they will overlap in the presence of competition, organisms occupy their “realized” type rather than their “fundamental” type. Interspecific competition occurs when these domains overlap. tossups.text: One equation to model this phenomenon sets the “empty-tower” velocity equal to the square of a “sphericity” term divided by 180 times the viscosity. Particles undergoing this process have a much smaller true Knudsen number than would be calculated using kinetic molecular theory’s prediction for mean free path. The onset of sustained turbulence in pipe flow is described by a universality class named for the (*) “directed” form of this phenomenon. Harry Kesten proved that, in a mathematical square lattice model with bond probability p, infinite open clusters prevent this phenomenon if p is greater than one-half. That statistical physics theory of this phenomenon studies connected clusters in random graphs. In isotropic media, this type of flow is described by setting flow rate proportional to permeability over viscosity in Darcy’s law. For 10 points, name this flow of a fluid through a porous medium like rock or sediment.
tossups.answer: percolation [accept descriptions like flow through porous medium, flow through packed medium before it is stated; prompt on just flow] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: Specimens for this technique begin as aqueous solutions that are applied onto glow-discharged hydrophilic carbon film grids before being blotted with filter paper to confine the solution to the grid’s holes. The Fourier shell correlation cutoff of 0.143 is implemented in the analysis of data gathered by this procedure. Its images are defocused for increased phase contrast, and thus must be modulated in the frequency space by the phase contrast transfer function. This method, which was used to simultaneously investigate (*) three rotational states of the yeast V-ATP·ase, produces images by aligning and sub-volume averaging many low-resolution images of individual proteins. Its single-particle reconstruction variant is competitive with X-ray crystallography. Samples are vitrified in liquid ethane and sliced into thin sections in—for 10 points—what method, which won its creators the 2017 Nobel Prize in Chemistry and uses electron beams to image low-temperature samples?
tossups.answer: cryo-electron microscopy [or cryo-EM, or electron cryomicroscopy or cryo-TEM or ECT or electron cryo-tomography or cryo-electron tomography or cryo-ET or CET; prompt on scanning electron microscopy or transmission electron microscopy] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.text: In 2009, one type of these drugs received a black box warning due to risk of gangrene via subcutaneous injection or IV push. One of these drugs which only has action against the second isotype of their namesake receptor is also a potent anti-androgen; that drug causes a reduction in the transmembrane levels of an H+/K+ ATP-ase. Their first-generation types block both the central and peripheral receptors of their namesake neurotransmitter, while their second-generation types include (*) feno·fexadine, ce·tiri·zine, and loratadine. These drugs counter the action of a cell type that is activated by complement activation byproducts or cross-linking of surface I·g·E receptors. Diphenhydramine is one of these drugs, which promote dilation of bronchial smooth muscle and vasoconstriction of post-capillary venules, treating breathing issues and hives. The chemical product of mast cells is opposed by—for 10 points—what class of drugs, of which Benadryl is a member?
tossups.answer: antihistamines [or histamine receptor antagonists; accept H1 or H2 antagonists until…?; anti-prompt on any specific antihistamines, like promethazine, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, Benadryl, fenofexadine, cetirizine, or loratadine] <Science - Biology>

tossups.text: Michael Bender discovered that insolation variation alters these structures’ gas composition, a fact that can be used to establish the chronology of orbital tuning. Major variations over time in the fluxes of terrestrial iron and calcium found in these objects from the Dome C site reflect fluctuations in the amount of Aeolian dust arriving from Patagonia. EPICA, GISP, and GRIP are consortia formed to collect these objects from sites like Valkyrie Dome. They’re not from the ocean, but the occurrence of Dansgaard-Oeschger events was first discovered in these objects by measuring the (*) fractionation of oxygen-18 and deuterium within them. These objects, which provide the highest-resolution temperature record through the Middle and Late Pleistocene, can be up to three kilometers long and contain air bubbles trapped in clathrates that are used to measure past atmospheric gas concentrations. For 10 points, name these objects which are drilled at sites like Vostok in Antarctica.
tossups.answer: ice cores [prompt on partial answer] <Science - Other>

tossups.text: In Indian string instruments, this kind of component is used to produce a namesake “buzzing” effect called jivari or javari. By contrast with its cousin the gǔzhēng [goo-JUHNG], the gǔqín [goo-CHEEN] only has one of these components. Following their mentor Glenn Branca, Lee Ranaldo and Thurston Moore often modified their instruments to include an extra one of these parts. Players of the koto use thirteen small, white examples of these components. Higher-gain (*) pickups are typically located adjacent to this component. Unlike a Bigsby, the whammy bar on a Fender Stratocaster is hooked up to this part of the instrument. By contrast with sul tasto, the screechy effect of sul ponticello is achieved by bowing over this part of the instrument. This part of a violin lies between the two f-holes and transmits vibrations to the upper soundboard. For 10 points, name this part of an instrument that supports the strings.
tossups.answer: bridges [accept bridge pickups or third bridge guitars] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.text: These functions can be uniquely written as the difference of two-positive valued examples of them, using the Hahn and Jordan decomposition theorems. The existence of a unique one of these functions is guaranteed in order to allow the representation of positive linear functionals by one of the Riesz Representation Theorems. The domain of these functions must always include sets of the type “G-delta” and “F-sigma.” Iterated functions that leave this kind of function invariant are the subject of the Poincaré Recurrence Theorem. The set of representatives of (*) R-quotient-Q in the unit interval does not fall within the domain of one of these functions, by a theorem of Vitali. One of these functions that takes values between 0 and 1 and has a value of 1 for the entire sample space is often used in general probability theory. These functions are defined over sigma-algebras. For 10 points, name these functions used to define the Lebesgue integral.
tossups.answer: measures [accept more specific answers like Lebesgue measures] <Science - Other>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney. tossups.text: An anomaly in one of these values is potentially explained by a new massive spin-1 Z′ [“Z prime”] boson. Another one of these values is theoretically predicted by using a summation of (*) 12,672 Feynman diagrams and has recently been measured to three parts in 10 to the 13. tossups.text: In contrast to alkyl sulfoxides, allylic sulfoxides undergo this reaction rapidly at moderate temperatures via a sulfenate ester intermediate that can be trapped by a nucleophile like tri·methoxy·phosphine. This process is the consequence of another process that produces a Q-branch on the rovibrational spectra of (*) pyramidal compounds; that other process occurs via quantum tunneling. Enolate formation causes this process to occur but isolated to the alpha-carbon atom. tossups.text: A protein hypothesized to control this process was originally posited by Mikhail Chailakhyan (“chy-lahkh-YAHN”); that protein forms a heterodimer with the transcription factor FD. In response to low temperature, the long noncoding RNA COLDAIR induces competence for this process by silencing FLC, which de-represses FT, FD, and SOC1. GIGANTEA and CONSTANS link this process to circadian rhythms, whose timing separates short-day and long-day organisms. Three sets of overlapping homeotic genes drive this process in the (*) apical meristem in the ABC model of it. The calyx and corolla are formed during this process, which also forms reproductive structures that contain pollen. For 10 points, name this process in which a structure containing stamens, pistils, sepals, and petals forms during angiosperm development.
tossups.answer: flower development [or flowering; or florescence; accept equivalents; prompt on blossoming or blooming; prompt on development or plant development] <EM, Biology: Dev/Plant>

tossups.text: This theory predicts both a spectral index of one and a random distribution of temperature fluctuations at the surface of last scattering. This theory is quantized by a scalar field whose coupling constant, denoted with the Greek letter xi (“k’sigh”), characterizes coupling with gravitons. This theory is the most widely accepted explanation for why some causal (“CAUSE-al”) patches cannot be observed, which is termed the horizon problem, but it does not completely account for (*) anisotropies (“an-eye-SAW-truh-peez”) observed by the COBE (“KO-bee”) satellite. Alan Guth (“gooth”) proposed this theory, whose namesake process took place 10-to-the-negative-36 seconds [emphasize] after a singularity 13 billion years ago. For 10 points, name this theory, according to which the universe expanded very rapidly for a short period after the Big Bang.
tossups.answer: cosmic inflation [do not accept or prompt on “Big Bang”] <WA, Astronomy>

tossups.text: These proteins are inhibited by aphidicolin (“uh-FID-uh-CO-leen”). MDA uses one of these proteins isolated from phi-29. Casposons encode a B family of these proteins, one of which was extracted from P. furiosus. They’re not antibodies, but the lambda and mu forms of these proteins participate in VDJ recombination. PCNA is a clamp protein that improves the processivity of these proteins. One form of these proteins has (*) bi-directional exonuclease activity for proofreading. These proteins, which are initially recruited to Ori (“OR-ee”) sites, synthesize Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand. By cleaving a pyrophosphate group off of an incoming dNTP, these proteins create products in the 5-prime to 3-prime direction. For 10 points, name these proteins that synthesize DNA.
tossups.answer: DNA polymerases [prompt on polymerase until “DNA” is read, but accept after] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.text: This theory’s equations are rewritten in terms of vectors that are typically denoted l, n, m, and m-bar in the tetrad formalism. Maximally symmetric solutions within this theory in which the vacuum energy density is positive are named for Willem de Sitter (“VILL-um duh SIT-tur”). This theory accurately predicted a shift of 1.75 arcseconds in the apparent position of the Hyades (“HY-uh-deez”) cluster during a solar eclipse. When expressed in geometric units, an equation central to this theory has a term of eight pi times the (*) stress-energy tensor. For 10 points, name this theory of gravity formulated by Albert Einstein, which has a “special” counterpart.
tossups.answer: general relativity [or GR; prompt on relativity; do not accept or prompt on “gravity” or “gravitation”] <WA, Physics>

tossups.text: Every finite group is the group of symmetries of one of these objects by Frucht’s theorem. It’s not a table, but groups can be represented using one of these objects named for Cayley. Matrix representations of these objects include the Laplacian matrix and the adjacency matrix. Some of these objects called snarks contain a substructure named for Julius Petersen, which itself is a common counterexample. If one of these structures does not contain (*) K-sub-5 or K-sub-3-3 as a minor, then it is planar according to Wagner’s theorem. Euler (“OY-ler”) used these objects to solve the Bridges of Königsberg problem. Examples of these objects include bipartite and complete ones. For 10 points, name these mathematical objects consisting of vertices and edges.
tossups.answer: graphs [accept directed graphs or oriented graphs or digraphs; prompt on network or diagram] <NC, Math>

tossups.text: An R-module Q has this property if every homomorphism out of a left ideal of R into Q can be extended to all of R, according to Baer’s criterion. In the short exact sequence consisting of maps from 0 to A to B to C to 0, the map from A to B has this property. To prove that a homomorphism has this property, f-of-x is set equal to f-of-y and it is shown that x must equal y. If m is greater than n, then a linear transformation from Rm to Rn (*) cannot have this property, which is equivalent to having a trivial kernel. A surjective map with this property is bijective. This property is required for an inverse function to have a unique output for every input. The function x-squared does not have this property because its graph fails the horizontal line test. For 10 points, name this property in which each output of a function is reached from exactly one input.
tossups.answer: injective [or one-to-one or injection] <NC, Math>

tossups.formatted_text: A 2019 Science paper reported the kinase PfCLK3 as a novel drug target in members of this genus. It’s not trypanosoma, but members of this genus have around 60 var genes that they can switch on and off to express different versions of their PfEMP1 protein on host cell surfaces. In host cells, this genus undergoes 13 to 14 rounds of cell division in schizogony (“skizz-OGG-uh-nee”), which ultimately produces a multinucleate schizont (“SKIZZ-ont”). An unusual peroxide bridge is found in a sesquiterpene (“SESS-qui-TER-peen”) lactone drug that treats infection by members of this genus, called (*) artemisinin. The ovale (“oh-VAL-ay”), vivax, and falciparum (“fal-SIP-uh-rum”) members of this genus most commonly infect humans, and are all carried by the common Anopheles (“uh-NOFF-uh-leez”) mosquito. For 10 points, name this genus of eukaryotes that are responsible for causing malaria.
tossups.formatted_answer: Plasmodium <RN, Biology: Immuno>

tossups.text: A polyomavirus that infects cells that detect this sense can trigger malignancy in its host when the helicase domain of its LT antigen is deleted. A sensor for this sense in crayfish was one of the first characterized examples of stochastic resonance in biology. The YbdG and Piezo channels transduct this sense. The carotid sinus and aortic arch are two locations that include receptors of this sense known as baroreceptors. Receptors for this sense are divided into (*) slow and fast-adapting and are innervated by A-beta fibers. Those receptors include Merkel cells and the onion-shaped Pacinian corpuscle. Receptors for this sense can be found in the stratum basale or within hair follicles. For 10 points, name this sense that is used to detect movement or pressure on the skin.
tossups.answer: touch [or stretch or mechanoreception; accept pressure until read] <RN, Biology: Medicine>

tossups.text: Integer multiples of the square of this quantity divided by Planck’s constant are the “plateaus” observed in the fractional quantum Hall effect. Values of one-third times this quantity are only possessed by color-confined particles such as (*) quarks. tossups.text: This effect is encoded by the negative f u term in the horizontal momentum equation. To prevent it from contributing higher-order terms, this effect is assumed to vary linearly along the beta-plane. When this effect is assumed to be equal and opposite to the PGF, wind blows parallel to isobars; that approximation is useful at the synoptic scale and is called geostrophic. When this phenomenon combines with drag, Ekman (*) spirals result, in which a rotating column of water moves at an angle to the wind. Its namesake parameter equals the sine of the latitude times twice the Earth’s rotation rate. This phenomenon explains why hurricanes rotate counter-clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere, but clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. For 10 points, name this effect caused by Earth’s rotation, in which objects deflect to the right in the Northern Hemisphere.
tossups.answer: Coriolis effect [or Coriolis force] <JZ, Earth Science>

tossups.text: In 2019, this constant was redefined such that the fine-structure constant equals [read slowly] “this quantity, times c, times e-squared, all over two times Planck’s constant.” The product of this quantity with the speed of light equals approximately 377 ohms. This constant’s units are equivalent to [read slowly] “seconds squared, divided by farads times meters,” as can be shown by rearranging Maxwell’s formula. This constant can be experimentally measured by finding the force between two wires of known length, current, and separation. It used to equal exactly (*) 4 pi times 10-to-the-negative-7 henries per meter. The current enclosed by a loop of wire, times this constant, equals the line integral of the B-field along that loop by Ampère’s circuit law. tossups.text: Epithelioid examples of these cells fuse to form multi-nucleated giant cells in granulomatous (“gran-yuh-LOM-uh-tuss”) diseases like sarcoidosis. These cells use heme oxygenase to generate biliverdin, a critical step in red blood cell breakdown in the spleen. Whether these cells metabolize arginine to ornithine is used to categorize them into M1 and M2 subtypes, and like their precursors, they express CD68. Alveolar (“al-vee-OH-lur”) examples of these cells are reservoirs for (*) Mycobacterium tuberculosis. These cells are often characterized by the tissue they reside in, and are also known as microglia in the CNS and Kupffer cells in the liver. Like dendritic cells and B cells, these cells present antigens to T cells. For 10 points, name these cells produced by the differentiation of monocytes, whose name means “big eater.”
tossups.answer: macrophages [prompt on white blood cells or leukocytes or monocytes] <RN, Biology: Immuno>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

tossups.text: Like rhenium and gold, this element forms a heptafluoride that is a strong oxidizing agent. This is the heavier element taken up by a symporter that is inhibited by the pertechnetate (“per-TEK-nuh-tate”) ion. This element’s methyl derivative reacts with a square planar iridium complex in the first step of the Cativa process. One isotope of this element decays by electron capture to tellurium-123, a reaction used in SPECT imaging. An ionic compound of this element and silver is used in both cloud seeding and photographic film. The (*) triatomic form of this element reacts with starch to form a purple complex, a phenomenon that is used in a popular clock reaction and Lugol’s test. Of the elements that are diatomic at STP, this element is the heaviest. For 10 points, name this halogen that is added to salt to prevent goiter.
tossups.answer: iodine [prompt on I] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.text: In early 2019, Ionis (“eye-OH-niss”) Pharmaceuticals began clinical trials for an antisense oligonucleotide-based therapy for this disease. An unusual disease similar to this one in Black South Africans is caused by mutations in JPH3. Inhibition of VMAT2 (“V-mat-2”) by tetrabenazine (“tetra-ben-uh-zeen”) is one treatment for this disease. Because the gene that encodes a protein central to this disease is more unstable in spermatogenesis than oogenesis (“oh-oh-genesis”), children of an affected father have an earlier age of onset, a phenomenon called (*) paternal anticipation. The striatum is damaged early in this disease, which is caused by the expansion of a CAG repeat in the polyglutamine tract of the protein HTT. For 10 points, name this autosomal dominant disease whose sufferers experience involuntary movements called chorea (“COR-ee-uh”).
tossups.answer: Huntington’s disease <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.text: This scientist is the alphabetically-last namesake of a method to calculate potential energy curves for diatomic atoms from their rotational–vibrational spectra along with Klein and Rees. An exotic state of matter in which a large atom contains smaller atoms in between its nucleus and electrons is known as this scientist’s polaron. Helium 2-plus is the first known example of one of this man’s (*) molecules, which have high principal quantum numbers. His constant of roughly 1.09 times 10-to-the-7 inverse meters is used to calculate the wavelengths of the Balmer and Lyman series. His namesake equation relates the initial and final energy levels of an atomic transition to its emitted wavelength. For 10 points, name this physicist who developed an equation used to calculate the wavelengths of light emitted by energy level changes in the hydrogen atom.
tossups.answer: Johannes Rydberg [accept Rydberg equation or Rydberg constant or Rydberg polaron] <RN, Physics>

tossups.text: Several models of this entity, including the 720-degree HDGM, use data from the ESA’s Swarm project. The fact that this entity isn’t perfectly concentric results in the South Atlantic (*) Anomaly, where this entity is weakened by the Van Allen belts. tossups.answer: Earth’s magnetic field [or geomagnetic field or geomagnetism; or Earth’s magnetosphere; prompt on ferromagnetism or magnetic field or magnetosphere or magnetic pole or pole] <EM, Earth Science>

tossups.text: These proteins are the substrate for a family of enzymes inhibited by vorinostat. Class III examples of those enzymes that modify these proteins lack a zinc cofactor and are called sirtuins (“sir-TOO-ins”). A domain unique to these proteins contains 3 alpha helices and two loops and allow them to form dimers through a handshake. David Allis and Michael Grunstein won the 2019 Lasker Award for decoding the effects of post-translational modifications on these proteins’ tails, often called their namesake code. These proteins are rich in (*) lysine and arginine residues, which are often methylated or acetylated. One of these proteins binds to linker DNA. Four different types of these highly conserved proteins are combined to form the nucleosome, which in turn binds to scaffolding proteins to form chromatin. For 10 points, DNA wraps around what highly basic packaging proteins?
tossups.answer: histones [prompt on nucleosome until read] <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.formatted_answer: nuclear fusion [accept inertial confinement fusion; accept thermonuclear fusion; accept muon-catalyzed fusion; prompt on ICF with “what does ICF stand for?”; do not accept or prompt on “nuclear fission”] <GC, Physics>

tossups.answer: reductions [accept reductive eliminations; accept reduction potential; accept reducing agent; prompt on redox reactions; prompt on electrochemical reactions or electrolysis] <GC, Chemistry> Bonuses

tossups.text: Adiabatic warming of air as a result of one of these objects causes Foehn [fain] winds. These objects induce standing wave formations that can drive the formation of lenticular clouds. These objects cause air masses to undergo orographic lift, which can increase their relative humidity to 100%, causing precipitation. The fact that regions on the leeward side of these objects are dry is called the (*) rain shadow effect. These objects are common example of an alpine climate, since trees cannot grow above the tree line on them. For 10 points, name these objects which comprise the Cascade and Appalachian ranges.
tossups.answer: mountains [or mountain ranges] <GC, Earth Science>

tossups.text: A square matrix can be transformed by a change of basis operation into one described by this term if and only if the sum of the dimensions of its eigenspaces is equal to its dimension. Matrices with the property described by this term are both upper triangular and lower triangular, and their only nonzero elements form a line between the upper left and lower right (*) corners. Given a regular polygon with n sides, the number of segments described by this term is equal to half the product of n and “n minus three.” A square has two of these things, and their length is equal to the side length times root 2. For 10 points, give this term for lines which are neither horizontal nor vertical.
tossups.answer: diagonal <CT, Mathematics>

tossups.text: The detonation-deflagration transition occurs at this quantity. tossups.answer: the speed of sound [or the velocity of sound; accept Mach 1 before “Mach”] <GC, Physics>

tossups.text: Forcing transitions in a quantum harmonic oscillator while in the Lamb-Dicke regime allows one to perform the “resolved sideband” type of this task. One approach to this task, proposed by Claude Cohen-Tannoudji, uses counter-propagating beams to produce a polarization gradient and is named for Sisyphus. A common method of doing this has a limit equal to h-bar times the linewidth over 2 times Boltzmann's constant, and requires a laser to be tuned slightly below the transition frequency to preferentially select atoms. That method of doing this named for the Doppler effect won Steven Chu the 1997 Nobel Physics prize. The “dilution” version of this process can be performed with no moving parts by mixing two isotopes of liquid helium. For 10 points, name this process which can be performed by dunking an object in liquid nitrogen.
tossups.answer: cooling [accept obvious equivalents; accept specific types like Doppler cooling or Sisyphus cooling]  <Science Physics - Mitchell>

tossups.text: Minimizing the integral of the square of one form of this quantity is equivalent to minimizing the Willmore energy. On a boundaryless manifold, integrating one form of this quantity gives two pi times the Euler characteristic by the Gauss-Bonnet theorem. This quantity and torsion are the two scalars in the Frenet-Serret formulas. This quantity equals the norm of the rate of change of the tangent vector with respect to arc length and is identically equal to one-over-R for a circle of radius R. For 10 points, give this quantity typically denoted kappa, which measures how much a surface deviates from flatness.

tossups.text: Two of these non-diode devices are used in buck converters for active rectification. One variant of these devices uses modulation of thermionic emission to get over an energy barrier, a method which caps this device's subthreshold voltage. These devices are created through PNP or NPN junctions. tossups.text: Summers et. al suggested a potential therapy for this disease involving trichuris suis, a type of whipworm. tossups.text: The set of functions with this property on a connected smooth manifold comprise its zero-th de Rham cohomology group. A real-valued function has this property if there is an alpha greater than one for which it is alpha-Hölder continuous. Any continuous function from the real numbers to the integers must possess this property, because the integers are totally disconnected. tossups.text: It's not cerium, but all variants of the nonlinear Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction involve this element, which is usually provided by a potassium salt. Alexander Borodin discovered how to produce compounds containing this element from silver carboxylates, which was later generalized to the Hunsdiecker reaction. The past use of this element's sodium and potassium salts as anticonvulsants resulted in a disease named for it. An emulsifier commonly used in soft drinks consists of triglycerides with ligands of this element, and is currently banned in the EU. An indicator which turns from yellow to blue above pH 7.6 contains 2 atoms of this element bonded to thymol groups, and adding this element to an unsaturated compound causes it to lose its color in a common text for alkenes. The only non-metal to be liquid at room temperature is, for 10 points, what reddish-brown halogen?
tossups.answer: bromine <Science Chemistry - Mitchell>

tossups.text: The size distribution of these things changes from -3/2 power-law scaling to -10/3 above the Hinze scale, and their shape is characterized by the Morton and Eötvös (airt-varsh) numbers. In 1972, neutral current was first detected by the Gargamelle Collaboration which generated these things within superheated Freon. A second order differential equation describes the variation in radius of these things and includes a far field pressure term scaled by density; that equation is the Rayleigh-Plesset equation. The imploding of these things causes shockwaves and sonoluminescence during cavitation. The principle that charged particles form these things led Donald Glaser to create a “chamber” that uses these things to detect particle events. For 10 points, name these globular objects, typically pockets of gas trapped off in liquids.
tossups.answer: bubbles [accept liquid drops until “spherical”]  <Science Physics - Etzkorn>

tossups.text: The performance-enhancing drug Meldonium inhibits CRAT, an enzyme that reacts this molecule with carnitine. Some sulfate-reducing bacteria oxidize this molecule to produce carbon dioxide in a reverse form of the Wood-Ljungdahl (Lyoong-dahl) pathway. This molecule is synthesized by a three-enzyme complex with E1, E2, and E3 subunits, the first of which requires a thiamine pyrophosphate cofactor. During starvation, thiophorase converts beta-hydroxybutyrate and other ketone bodies into this molecule outside the liver. A thiolase forms carbon-carbon bonds between two units of this molecule in the first step of the mevalonate pathway. Each round of beta oxidation cleaves two carbons from a fatty acid to release this molecule, which also reacts with oxaloacetate to begin the citric acid cycle. For 10 points, name this molecule formed from the oxidation of pyruvate.
tossups.answer: acetyl-CoA [or acetyl coezyme A]  <Science Biology - Narayan>  Bonuses

tossups.text: A set of m of these quantities is listed in ascending order, and the kth largest is compared to k over m times another quantity, in the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure. Negative two times the sum of the logarithms of a set of these quantities is analyzed in a method of meta-analysis named for Fisher. An upper bound on a set of m of these quantities is divided by m in a technique that applies the union bound to control the FWER, which is the Bonferroni correction. By definition, these quantities are uniformly distributed under H0 (H sub zero). The multiple comparisons problem can lead to the so-called “hacking” of these quantities, whose size is often depicted using one, two, or three asterisks when reporting the results of a hypothesis test. For 10 points, name these quantities whose size relative to the significance level determines whether the null hypothesis is rejected.
tossups.answer: p-value [or asymptotic significance; or probability value; do not accept or prompt on “significance” or “significance level”]  <Science Math - Morrison>

tossups.text: The most recent calibration curve used in this technique includes data from foraminifera and speleothems and is known as INTCAL13. tossups.text: De Georgia et. al ran a pilot study to reduce lesions from these events by inducing hypothermia, a technique they called COOL AID. One type of these events is treated with permissive hypertension 24 hours after. The TOAST criteria can be used to categorize these events, whose areas of impact can be viewed from hyperintense regions on a diffusion weighted image. The two largest categorizations of these events are ischemic and hemorrhagic. Transient ischemic attacks are sometimes described as a “mini” one of these events. The mnemonic FAST is used for these events as they are often accompanied by pronator drift, facial drooping, arm weakness, and speech difficulties. These events are alternatively referred to as “cerebrovascular accidents.” For 10 points, name these events where brain tissue is deprived of oxygen.
tossups.answer: (vascular) strokes [accept cerebral (infarction/accident/incident), cerebrovascular accident, or CVA until “cerebro-” prompt afterwards; prompt on brain attack]  <Science Biology - Etzkorn>

tossups.text: A polymer of this compound is added to opioids to reduce their adverse gastrointestinal side effects in naloxegol. The co-polymerization of this compound and terephthalic (TUH-rep-THALL-ick) acid generates the thermoplastic PET. This compound can be added to carbonyls to protect them via the formation of a dioxolane group. This compound can be produced by the base-catalysed ring opening of ethylene oxide. Poisoning with this simplest vicinal diol is often treated with ethanol. For 10 points, name this common antifreeze compound, a two-carbon diol.

tossups.text: Diffraction patterns always have a form of this property due to Friedel's law. In one or two dimensions, if this property is continuous, it must persist under short-range interactions and finite temperatures, according to the Mermin-Wagner theorem. If this property did not persist, the correlation function for the corresponding Goldstone boson would diverge. The existence of this property for the weak force implies that the W and Z bosons should be massless, which is why the Higgs mechanism locally violates this property. Noether's (NUR-tehr's) first theorem states that for each one of these properties that is differentiable, there exists a corresponding conservation law. Spontaneous breaking of this property can solve the hierarchy problem, which is why some propose this property for bosons and fermions.
